column1: Albany  (Nyungar: Kinjarling) is a port city in the Great Southern region in the Australian state of Western Australia
column3: the state capital. Albany is the oldest colonial settlement in Western Australia
column4: predating Perth and Fremantle by over two years.

column1: The city centre is at the northern edge of Princess Royal Harbour
column2: which is a part of King George Sound. The central business district is bounded by Mount Clarence to the east and Mount Melville to the west. The city is in the local government area of the City of Albany.

column1: The Albany settlement was founded on 26 December 1826
column2: as a military outpost of New South Wales as part of a plan to forestall French ambitions in the region. To that end
column3: on 21 January 1827
column6: formally took possession of the western third of the continent for the British Crown.During the last decade of the 19th century the town served as a gateway to the Eastern Goldfields. For many years
column7: it was the colony's only deep-water port
column8: having a place of eminence on shipping services between Britain and its Australian colonies. The opening of the Fremantle Inner Harbour in 1897
column10: saw its importance as a port decline
column11: after which the town's industries turned primarily to agriculture

column1: Today as a city it is the southern terminus for tourism in the region
column3: which is known for its natural environment and preservation of heritage. The town has a role in the ANZAC legend
column4: being the last port of call for troopships departing Australia in the First World War. On 1 November 2014 the Australian and New Zealand Prime Ministers opened the National Anzac Centre in Mount Clarence
column6: to commemorate 100 years since the first ANZAC troops departed from King George Sound. Approximately 40
column7: 000 people attended the commemoration events held between 30 October and 2 November 2014. Also an auxiliary submarine base for the US Navy's 7th Fleet was developed during the Second World War in the event the submarine base at Fremantle was lost. Also in the harbour was an RAN Naval Installation which provided for alongside refuelling from four 5000 ton fuel tanks.

column2: the Albany settlement was named Frederick Town in honour of Prince Frederick
column3: Duke of York and Albany. In 1831
column4: the settlement was transferred to the control of the Swan River Colony and renamed Albany by Lieutenant-Governor James Stirling.The name of the area in the Nyungar language of the local indigenous Menang people is Kinjarling
column5: which has been said to mean "place of plenty" and "place of rain". In 2020
column7: as part of an official dual-naming project
column8: to give prominence to Kinjarling as the city's indigenous name.

column1: Kinjarling was home to Menang Noongar indigenous tribes during the summer season. The Menang people would sometimes camp near "Boondie Yokine" – roughly translated as Dog Rock.Early European explorers discovered evidence of fish traps located on Emu Point and on the French
column3: River. Vancouver made attempts to find the inhabitants of the area but only found bark dwellings that were unoccupied. Later explorers made contact and were told to leave
column4: but were accepted when they did not. Most of the exploration was made to survey the land and sea and assess the resources for further exploitation. The explorers only occasionally noted the Noongars they encountered. Native treatment laws and programs have affected the tribes since settlement.

column1: There are a number of heritage buildings in Albany;  see List of heritage places in the City of Albany and Category:Heritage places in Albany

column2: Strawberry Hill was established in 1827 as a government farm to feed the colonial soldiers stationed around King George's Sound. It is the oldest farm in Western Australia. The homestead
column3: which became the home of the Government Resident in 1836
column4: is an example of a colonial gentleman's residence. After a chequered history the property was vested in the National Trust WA in 1964 and is now a house museum.

column3: built in 1832 by the Morley Brothers. It is now maintained by the Albany Historical Society.

column1: St John's Church (1841–1848) is a stone building with shingled roofs in the Old Colonial Gothick Picturesque style. Set among trees
column2: it was designed to be part of an overall contrived picturesque scene in the manner of an English garden landscape.

column1: Scots Uniting Church (1892) was designed in the Victorian Academic Gothic style by Melbourne architect Evander McIver and built with local granite stonework.
The complex now known as The Residency Museum was established in 1850 as a depot for the Convict Establishment in Albany. It is an L shaped
column3: masonry building with a timber framed
column4: timber shingled roof. In 1873 it was converted into the Resident Magistrate's home. It now serves as a museum.

column1: The Victorian Free Classical Revival style Town Hall (1888) is a two-storey stone building with a prominent clock tower
column3: the main street  of Albany. It has been put to many uses apart from council meetings
column4: including public entertainment and public meetings of all kinds and even as the venue for the first regional meeting of the State Parliament.

column1: The Old Post Office was built in two stages
column2: the first was designed in 1869 by J Manning
column3: the second
column5: was designed in 1896 by George Temple-Poole. It now houses the Albany campus of the University of Western Australia.

column2: constructed of Albany brick and granite with a tiled roof
column3: was designed in the Federation Romanesque style by the Public Works Department under the supervision of George Temple-Poole and Hillson Beasley in 1897.

column1: Another example of the work of George Temple Poole is the limestone and shingle Federation Arts and Crafts style Cottage Hospital
column2: designed in 1886 and completed in 1897. It is one of the oldest hospitals in the state and served as such until 1962. It is now occupied by the Vancouver Arts Centre (named after the explorer George Vancouver).Images of heritage buildings

column2: the urban population of Albany was 34
column3: 205 making it the state's sixth-largest population centre.

column1: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people made up 3.5% of the population.
74.3% of people were born in Australia. The next most common countries of birth were England 7.5%
column3: Philippines 1.6%

column1: 86.8% of people only spoke English at home. Other languages spoken at home included Filipino 0.7%
column3: Tagalog 0.6%

column1: The most common responses for religion were No Religion 37.4%
column3: with 10.4% not stated.

column1: The city centre of Albany is located between the hills of Mount Melville and Mount Clarence
column2: which look down into Princess Royal Harbour. Many beaches surround Albany
column3: with Middleton Beach being the closest to the town centre. Other popular beaches include Frenchman Bay and Muttonbird Island.

column1: Albany is 418 km (260 mi) SSE of the state capital
column3: to which it is linked by Albany Highway.

column1: Albany is a sub-region of the Great Southern region of Western Australia.
The Albany coastline is notorious for deaths due to king waves washing people off rocks.  The Torndirrup National Park features some of the more rugged coastline in the area. However
column2: there are many beaches that are safe and usable:
including Little Beach and Waterfall Beach

column1: Albany has a warm-summer Mediterranean climate (Köppen Csb) with dry
column3: mild
column5: and pleasant springs and autumns. Summers have short spells of very hot weather
column6: but cool ocean breeze brings relief
column7: especially during evenings and nights. The city is situated on what is promoted as the "Rainbow Coast"
column8: an appropriate title given the frequency of days with both sun and drizzle or showers. Albany has 44.8 clear days annually.

column2: with a long-term average of 144.0 mm (5.67 in). Rain in excess of 0.2 mm (0.01 in) occurs on two days out of every three during an average winter. The driest month is February with a mean of 22.9 mm (0.90 in).

column1: Albany received a record amount of rain on 20 November 2008 when violent storms swept across the Great Southern region. The town was flooded after 113.8 mm (4.48 in) of rain fell in a 24-hour period
column2: the highest amount recorded since rainfall records began in 1877. The wettest month on record was June 1920 when 292.8 mm (11.5 in) fell
column3: while February 1877 and February 1879 remain the only rainless months.
timber (wood chips) and agriculture. From 1952 to 1978 whaling was a major source of income and employment for the local population.
has been converted to a museum of whaling
column4: and features one of the 'Cheynes' whale chasers that were used for whaling in Albany. The station was the last operating whaling station in the southern hemisphere and the English-speaking world at the time of closure.The Western Power Wind Farm is located at Sand Patch

column9: and can generate up to 80% of the city's electricity usage.Albany has a number of historical sites including the Museum
column11: The Princess Royal Fortress (commonly known as The Forts) and Patrick Taylor Cottage
column12: one of the oldest dwellings in Western Australia
column13: c1832. Albany has a great deal of historical significance to Western Australia.

column1: Natural sights along the rugged coastline include the 'Natural Bridge' and the 'Gap'. The beaches have pristine white sand. The destroyer HMAS Perth was sunk in King George Sound in 2001 as a dive wreck. Albany is also close to two low mountain ranges

Albany is the southern terminus of the Bibbulmun Track walking trail.Albany is the southern terminus of the Munda Biddi Trail off-road cycling trail.Albany is home to HMAS Albany (based in Darwin) and the adopted home port of the Royal Australian Navy frigate HMAS Anzac. Albany is frequently visited by other warships.

Albany has a city bus service run by Love's Bus Service with five town routes. Albany is connected to Perth with road-coach services via Walpole and Bunbury; via Katanning and Northam; via Kojonup and Williams. Transwa coaches also serve Jerramungup
column3: a national independent regional airline
column4: provides  23 services a week between Perth and Albany Airport using 34-passenger turboprop Saab 340 aircraft.Albany was served by the Albany Progress passenger train from Perth until 1978. The railway station reopened as a tourist information centre in 1994.

These services are broadcast from Mount Clarence and cover the majority of the geographic area with some areas requiring signal to be received from the Southern Agricultural site at Mount Barker. Both these transmission sites employ vertical polarity. Furthermore
